case_name: Henry Golak Nath heirs v. State of Punjab and State of Mysore

facts.text: Three writ petitions were filed raising the validity of the Constitution (Seventeenth Amendment) Act, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Subbarao, C.J. These three writ petitions raise the important question of the validity of the Constitution Seventeenth Amendment Act, 1964.

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 153 of 1966 filed by petitioners against the State of Punjab and the Financial Commissioner, Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petition No. 153 of 1966, is filed by the petitioners therein against the State of Punjab and the Financial Commissioner, Punjab.

facts.text: Petitioners in Writ Petition No. 153 of 1966 are the son, daughter and grand-daughters of Henry Golak Nath.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are the son, daughter and grand-daughters of one Henry Golak Nath, who died on July 30, 1953.

facts.text: Henry Golak Nath died on July 30, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are the son, daughter and grand-daughters of one Henry Golak Nath, who died on July 30, 1953.

facts.text: Financial Commissioner held by order dated January 22, 1962 that 418 standard acres and 9 1/4 units was surplus in hands of petitioners under Punjab Security of Land Tenures Act X of 1953, read with s. 10-B.

anchor.surface_text: The Financial Commissioner, in revision against the order made by the Additional Commissioner, Jullundur Division, held by an order dated January 22, 1962 that an area of 418 standard acres and 9 1/4 units was surplus in the hands of the petitioners under the provisions of the Punjab Security of Land Tenures Act X of 1953, read with s. 10-B thereof.

facts.text: Petitioners alleged relevant provisions of Punjab Security of Land Tenures Act declaring surplus area void as infringing Articles 19(f), 19(g) and 14.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners, alleging that the relevant provisions of the said Act whereunder the said area was declared surplus were void on the ground that they infringed their rights under cls. f and g of Art. 19 and Art. 14 of the Constitution, filed a writ in this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution

facts.text: Petitioners filed writ in Supreme Court under Article 32 seeking declaration that Constitution (First Amendment) Act, 1951, Constitution (Fourth Amendment) Act, 1955, Constitution (Seventeenth Amendment) Act, 1964 affecting fundamental rights unconstitutional and s.10-B of Act X of 1953 void.

anchor.surface_text: for a direction that the Constitution First Amendment Act, 1951, Constitution Fourth Amendment Act, 1955, Constitution Seventeenth Amendment Act, 1964, insofar as they affected their fundamental rights were unconstitutional and inoperative and for a direction that s. 10-B of the said Act X of 1953 was void as violative of Arts. 14 and 19 1 f and g of the Constitution.

facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 202 and 203 of 1966 filed under Article 32 declaring Mysore Land Reforms Act (Act 10 of 1962) as amended by Act 14 of 1965 unconstitutional infringing Articles 14, 19 and 31.

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petitions Nos. 202 and 203 of 1966 were filed by different petitioners under Art. 32 of the Constitution for a declaration that the Mysore Land Reforms Act Act 10 of 1962 as amended by Act 14 of 1965, which fixed ceilings on land holdings and conferred ownership of surplus lands on tenants infringed Arts. 14, 19 and 31 of the Constitution

facts.text: States of Punjab and Mysore contended Acts saved by Constitution (Seventeenth Amendment) Act, 1964 amending Article 31A and including Acts in Ninth Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: The States of Punjab and Mysore, inter alia, contended that the said Acts were saved from attack on the ground that they infringed the fundamental rights of the petitioners by reason of the Constitution Seventeenth Amendment Act, 1964, which, by amending Art. 31-A of the Constitution and including the said two Acts in the 9th Schedule thereto, had placed them beyond attack.

facts.text: Mysore Land Reforms Act, 1962 (Act 10 of 1962) included as item 51 in Ninth Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: In the Ninth Schedule to the Constitution the Mysore Land Reforms Act, 1961, Mysore Act 10 of 1962 is included as item 51 and the Punjab Security of Land Tenures Act, 1953 Punjab Act 10 of 1953 is included as item 54.

facts.text: Punjab Security of Land Tenures Act, 1953 (Punjab Act 10 of 1953) included as item 54 in Ninth Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: In the Ninth Schedule to the Constitution the Mysore Land Reforms Act, 1961, Mysore Act 10 of 1962 is included as item 51 and the Punjab Security of Land Tenures Act, 1953 Punjab Act 10 of 1953 is included as item 54.

facts.text: Constitution (Seventeenth Amendment) Act, 1964 amended definition of estate and included the two Acts in Ninth Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: The definition of estate was amended and the Ninth Schedule was amended by including therein the said two Acts by the Constitution Seventeenth Amendment Act, 1964.

facts.text: 7 parties intervened in Writ Petition No. 153 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: In Writ Petition No. 153 of 1966, 7 parties intervened.

facts.text: One party intervened in Writ Petition No. 202 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: In Writ Petition No. 202 of 1966 one party intervened.

facts.text: Notice given to Advocates General of various States in first petition.

anchor.surface_text: In addition, in the first petition, notice was given to the Advocates General of various States.

facts.text: Supreme Court in Sankari Prasad Singh Deo v. Union of India held Parliament had power to amend Part III.

anchor.surface_text: The question of the amendability of the fundamental rights was considered by this Court earlier in two decisions, namely, Sri Sankari Prasad Singh Deo v. Union of India and State of Bihar 1952 S.C.R. 89, 105 and in Sajjan Singh v. State of Rajasthan .

facts.text: Supreme Court in Sajjan Singh v. State of Rajasthan upheld validity of Constitution (Seventeenth Amendment) Act, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The decision in Sajjan Singhs case , was given in the context of the question of the validity of the Constitution Seventeenth Amendment Act, 1964.

facts.text: Constitution (Seventeenth Amendment) Act, 1964 held void under Article 13(2) insofar as it takes away or abridges fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the Constitution Seventeenth Amendment Act, 1964, inasmuch as it takes away or abridges the fundamental rights is void under Art. 13 2 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Constitution came into force on January 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Constitution came into force on January 26, 1950.

facts.text: Constitution (First Amendment) Act, 1951 inserted Articles 31A and 31B with retrospective effect.

anchor.surface_text: The Constitution First Amendment Act, 1951, amended Arts. 15 and 19, and Arts. 31-A and 31-B were inserted with retrospective effect.
Constitution Seventeenth Amendment Act, 1964.

issues.text: the important question of the validity of the Constitution Seventeenth Amendment Act, 1964

anchor.surface_text: raise the important question of the validity of the Constitution Seventeenth Amendment Act, 1964. Writ Petition No. 153 of 1966, is filed by the petitioners therein against the State of Punjab and the Financial Commissioner, Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: the Mysore Land Reforms Act Act 10 of 1962  as amended by Act 14 of 1965, which fixed ceilings on land holdings and conferred ownership of surplus lands on tenants infringed Arts. 14, 19 and 31 of the Constitution and, therefore, was unconstitutional and void.

issues.text: the question of the amendability of the fundamental rights

anchor.surface_text: The question of the amendability of the fundamental rights was considered by this Court earlier in two decisions, namely, Sri Sankari Prasad Singh Deo v. Union of India and State of Bihar 1952 S.C.R. 89, 105  and in Sajjan Singh v. State of Rajasthan .

issues.text: The first question is whether amendment of the Constitution under Art. 368 is law within the meaning of Art. 13 2

anchor.surface_text: With this background let us proceed to consider the provisions of Art. 368, vis-a-vis Art. 13 2  of the Constitution. The first question is whether amendment of the Constitution under Art. 368 is law within the meaning of Art. 13 2 .

anchor.surface_text: Two questions arose in that case  1  Whether the amendment Act insofar it purported to take away or abridge the rights conferred by Part III of the Constitution fell within the prohibition of Art. 13 2  and  2 . Whether Articles 31-A and 31-B sought to make changes in Arts. 132, 136 or 226

issues.text: whether our decision should be given retrospective operation

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether our decision should be given retrospective operation. During the period between 1950 and 1967 i.e., 17 years, as many as 20 amendments were made in our Constitution.

issues.text: whether the impugned amendment detracts from the jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226 and the legislative powers of the States and therefore falls within the proviso to Art. 368

anchor.surface_text: The impugned amendment detracts from the jurisdiction of the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution and also the legislative powers of the States and therefore it falls within the scope of the proviso to Art. 368.

holdings.text: The Constitution (Seventeenth Amendment) Act, 1964, inasmuch as it takes away or abridges the fundamental rights is void under Art. 13(2) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the Constitution Seventeenth Amendment Act, 1964, inasmuch as it takes away or abridges the fundamental rights is void under Art. 13 2 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitutional amendments made under Art. 368 constitute 'law' within the meaning of Art. 13(2), which prohibits any law abridging fundamental rights in Part III; prior precedents upholding amendability overruled.

holdings.text: An amendment of the Constitution under Art. 368 is 'law' within the meaning of Art. 13(2).

anchor.surface_text: The first question is whether amendment of the Constitution under Art. 368 is law within the meaning of Art. 13 2 . ... In the premises, an amendment of the Constitution can be nothing but law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 368 prescribes only the procedure for amendment; the power derives from Parliament's residuary legislative power under Arts. 245-248, following standard legislative process, making it 'law' subject to Art. 13(2).

holdings.text: The decisions in Sankari Prasad Singh Deo v. Union of India and Sajjan Singh v. State of Rajasthan are overruled insofar as they held that Parliament could amend Part III fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: The question of the amendability of the fundamental rights was considered by this Court earlier in two decisions, namely, Sri Sankari Prasad Singh Deo v. Union of India ... The conflict between the majority and the minority in Sajjan Singhs case , falls to be resolved in this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior harmonious construction reading Art. 13 subject to Art. 368 rejected; 'law' in Art. 13(2) includes constitutional amendments as they follow legislative process.

holdings.text: This decision overruling prior precedents on amendability of fundamental rights will operate prospectively only and not retrospectively.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether our decision should be given retrospective operation. During the period between 1950 and 1967 i.e., 17 years, as many as 20 amendments were made in our Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Retrospective application would cause chaos in agrarian reforms and unsettle 17 years of constitutional amendments and state laws; prospective overruling preserves past transactions while protecting future rights.

holdings.text: Article 368 lays down only the procedure for amending the Constitution; the power to amend derives from Parliament's legislative power under Articles 245, 246 and 248.

anchor.surface_text: The marginal note to Art. 368 describes that article as one prescribing the procedure for amendment. ... Under Art. 245, subject to the provisions of the Constitution. Parliament may make laws

holdings.reasoning_summary: Marginal note and text of Art. 368 indicate procedural steps only; residuary legislative powers include authority to amend Constitution as 'law', subject to constitutional limits like Art. 13(2).

holdings.text: The inclusion of the Punjab Security of Land Tenures Act, 1953 and Mysore Land Reforms Act, 1962 in the Ninth Schedule by the Seventeenth Amendment does not protect them from challenge under fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: In the Ninth Schedule to the Constitution the Mysore Land Reforms Act, 1961, Mysore Act 10 of 1962 is included as item 51 and the Punjab Security of Land Tenures Act, 1953 Punjab Act 10 of 1953 is included as item 54. ... The result is that the Constitution Seventeenth Amendment Act, 1964, inasmuch as it takes away or abridges the fundamental rights is void under Art. 13 2 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Seventeenth Amendment invalid under Art. 13(2); Arts. 31A and 31B as amended cannot save state laws from Part III challenge.

holdings.text: Fundamental rights in Part III have a transcendental and paramount position and cannot be abrogated or abridged by constitutional amendment.

anchor.surface_text: fundamental rights are given a transcendental position under our Constitution and are kept beyond the reach of Parliament. ... The result is that the Constitution Seventeenth Amendment Act, 1964, inasmuch as it takes away or abridges the fundamental rights is void under Art. 13 2 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Constitution places Part III beyond parliamentary reach via Art. 13(2); amendments abridging them void; supported by Constituent Assembly intent and judicial precedents describing FRs as paramount.
